question: Question_06
statement:
Let

\begin{align*}f(x) = \begin{cases}  \frac{1}{2}\cos(x) & \hbox{if } x < a \\
x^2 + b & \hbox{if } x \geq a
\end{cases}\end{align*}

Find constants''a'' and \emph{b} such that $f$ is differentiable
everywhere. Justify your answer.
sols:
In order for $f(x)$ to be differentiable at \emph{a}, we have two
requirements: that the function be continous and derivatives from the
right and left of a point are the same.

Before we start, let us note that \emph{$f$} is surely, as a composition
of differentiable functions, differentiable at all points expect \emph{x
= a}. Hence we can focus our study on the point \emph{x = a}.

We begin with the second condition: that the derivative from the right
($x < a$) must be the same as the derivative from the left ($x > a$).
This means that we are trying to find the value \emph{a} such that

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
 -\frac{1}{2}\sin a = 2a\end{align*}

Simplifying a bit, this is the same as

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
 -\sin a = 4a\end{align*}

If we think about the function $-\sin x$ we know that it is bounded
between -1 and 1. If a was greater than 1/4, say, 1/2, the left side
would be less than one, while the right side would already be greater
than 2. So \emph{a} must be between -1/4 and 1/4 for this equation to
hold. In fact, the only place that the graphs of $- \sin x$ and
\emph{4x} intersect is at \emph{x = 0.} So \emph{a = 0.}

This satisfies the condition that the derivatives match; now we must
ensure that $f(x)$ is continuous. The function is defined everywhere, so
we must check that the limit at \emph{x = a} exists.

The limit from the left of \emph{x = 0} is

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
\lim_{x \to 0^-} f(x) = \lim_{x \to 0^-}\frac{1}{2}\cos x = \frac{1}{2}\end{align*}

The limit from the right of \emph{x = 0} is

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
\lim_{x \to 0^+} f(x) = \lim_{x \to 0^+}x^2 + b = b\end{align*}

These two limits must be equal, so we have \emph{b} = 1/2.
hints:
For a function to be differentiable at a point \emph{x = a}, it must be
continuous at \emph{a} and the derivative on both sides of \emph{a} must
be equal.
